The parameter estimation of the prognostic model consists of two steps: (i) feature extraction and (ii) regression parameters estimation. The first step, feature extraction, focuses on using the decentralized historical degradation signals from multiple users (i.e., ğ’™iâ¢jâ¢(t)subscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{ij}(t)bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t )) to calculate the MFPC-scores (i.e., ğœ»iâ¢jsubscriptğœ»ğ‘–ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)). The second step, regression parameters estimation, uses the features from the first step (i.e., ğœ»iâ¢jsubscriptğœ»ğ‘–ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and the historical TTFs (i.e., yiâ¢jsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—y_{ij}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) to estimate the regression parameters (i.e., Î²0,ğœ·,Ïƒsubscriptğ›½0ğœ·ğœ\beta_{0},\boldsymbol{\beta},\sigmaitalic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î² , italic_Ïƒ). Since the historical data is decentralized, both the feature extraction and coefficient estimation algorithms should be federated, which means that they can use data from all the users while keeping each userâ€™s data local and confidential. In this article, our contribution is to propose a federated feature extraction algorithm for applications with incomplete degradation signals, which will be discussed in Section 3. Regarding the second step, regression parameters estimation, we will employ the federated algorithm developed in [29].

In this section, we propose a federated feature extraction algorithm that computes the MFPC-scores (i.e., ğœ»iâ¢jsubscriptğœ»ğ‘–ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) using the decentralized incomplete degradation signals from multiple users while keeping each userâ€™s data local and confidential. To help understand the proposed federated algorithm, we will first review how to extract the MFPC-scores using centralized complete data (i.e., the data from all users are merged together for feature extraction) in Section 3.1. After that, the proposed federated algorithm using decentralized data will be discussed in Section 3.2.

In this section, we propose a federated feature extraction method that enables multiple users to utilize their incomplete degradation signals to compute their MFPC-scores (i.e., ğœ»iâ¢jsubscriptğœ»ğ‘–ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{ij}bold_italic_Î¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation (3)) while keeping each userâ€™s data local and confidential. Inspired by the feature extraction method and the remarks discussed in Section 3.1, we first develop a federated algorithm to detect the dominant subspace of the degradation signal matrix ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\boldsymbol{X}bold_italic_X (Section 3.2.1). This provides a general set of basis vectors of the dominant subspace. Next, we propose a federated algorithm that uses the general set of basis vectors of the dominant subspace and (incomplete and uncentered) degradation signals to calculate MFPC-scores (Section 3.2.2). Figure 1 provides an overview of the proposed federated feature extraction algorithm.

Utilizing their MFPC-scores {ğ’›i}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’›ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ¼\{\boldsymbol{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{I}{ bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and TTFs {ğ’šiâˆˆâ„Ji}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’šğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ½ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ¼\{\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{J_{i}}\}_{i=1}^{I}{ bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, all the Iğ¼Iitalic_I users can jointly train a prognostic model based on (log)-location-scale (LLS) regression. In this article, we will employ the federated LLS regression model developed in [29], which allows the Iğ¼Iitalic_I users to collaboratively train the prognostic model while keeping each userâ€™s MFPC-scores and TTFs local and confidential. The parameter estimation of the federated LLS regression utilizes maximum likelihood estimation, which is solved using gradient descent. Initially, the server randomly initializes the regression coefficients. Subsequently, each user downloads these initial coefficients and computes its local gradients using its local data (i.e., MFPC-scores and TTFs). These local gradients are then transmitted to the server, which aggregates them from all users and employs the aggregated gradients to update the regression coefficients. This updated set of coefficients is subsequently redistributed to each user for another round of updating, repeating this process until convergence is achieved. The federated LLS regression provides each user with the estimated regression parameters, which we denoted as Î²^0âˆˆâ„subscript^ğ›½0â„\hat{\beta}_{0}\in\mathbb{R}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R, ğœ·^âˆˆâ„K^ğœ·superscriptâ„ğ¾\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î² end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Ïƒ^âˆˆâ„^ğœâ„\hat{\sigma}\in\mathbb{R}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R (please refer to Equation (3)).

One of the limitations of the above subspace updating method is that it is computationally intensive since SVD has to be conducted on an NÃ—(K+1)ğ‘ğ¾1N\times(K+1)italic_N Ã— ( italic_K + 1 )-dimensional matrix ğ‘ªğ‘ª{\boldsymbol{C}}bold_italic_C for each update. Typically, Nğ‘Nitalic_N is an extremely large number given it is the number of observations in the longest degradation signal, while Kğ¾Kitalic_K is usually a small number since high-dimensional signals are often embedded in a relatively low-dimensional subspace. To address this challenge, we may decompose matrix ğ‘ªğ‘ª{\boldsymbol{C}}bold_italic_C as follows based on Equation (6):
